definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid obtained as ayellow crystalline substance by the oxidation of quinine.
A periodical work published once a quarter, or four times in ayear.
One who is versed in quinology.
A stanza of four lines rhyming alternately. Dryden.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the fatty acidseries, containing fifteen atoms of carbon; called also pentadecylicacid.
The body or office of the quindecemviri.

A plane surface with four equal sides and four right angles; asquare; hence, figuratively, anything having the outline of a square.At which command, the powers militant That stood for heaven, inmighty quadrate joined. Milton.
Tetragonal.
, Consisting of quirks; resembling a quirk. Barrow.
Occurring as the fifth, after four others also, occurring everyfifth day, reckoning inclusively; as, a quintan fever.-- n. (Med.)
Quinine.
The offspring of a mulatto and a white person; a personquarter-blooded. [Written also quarteron, quarteroon, and quateron.]
Of, pertaining to, or designating, the hill Collis Quirinalis,now Monte Quirinale (one of the seven hills of Rome), or a modernroyal place situated upon it. Also used substantively.
A proportional part or share; the share or proportion assignedto each in a division. "Quota of troops and money." Motley.
The quality of being quaint. Pope.
A negro of the West Indies.
Full of quirks; tricky; as, a quirky lawyer.
A flat file having the handle at one side, so as to be usedlike a plane.
Having four wings; -- said of insects.
A game at cards in which the object is to make fifteen points.
A complainant; a plaintiff.
Multiplied by five; increased to five times the amount;fivefold. Quintuple time (Mus.), a time having five beats in ameasure. It is seldom used.

The period of forty days during which the widow had theprivilege of remaining in the mansion house of which her husband diedseized. Quarantine flag, a yellow flag hoisted at the fore of avessel or hung from a building, to give warning of an infectiousdisease; -- called also the yellow jack, and yellow flag.
An ornamental foliation having four lobes, or foils.
Having five leaflets. Gray.
A quadrat.
See Quob.
To stir. [Obs.]He could not move nor quich at all. Spenser.
A green crystalline substance formed by the union of quinonewith hydroquinone, or as an intermediate product in the oxidation ofhydroquinone or the reduction of quinone. [Written also chinhydrone.]

According to the French notation, which is used on theContinent and in America, the cube of a million, or a unit witheighteen ciphers annexed; according to the English notation, a numberproduced by involving a million to the fifth power, or a unit withthirty ciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
Offerings formerly made to the mother church of a diocese onMid-Lent Sunday.
Having four feet.
A seeker; a pursuer. [Obs.] "Hot questrists after him." Shak.

The encampment on one of the principal passages round a placebesieged, to prevent relief and intercept convoys.(i) (Naut.) The after-part of a vessel's side, generallycorresponding in extent with the quarter-deck; also, the part of theyardarm outside of the slings.(j) (Her.) One of the divisions of an escutcheon when it is dividedinto four portions by a horizontal and a perpendicular line meetingin the fess point.
See Quitch grass.
Fourfold; folded or doubled twice. Quadruplex system (ElectricTelegraph), a system by which four messages, two in each direction,may be sent simultaneously over the wire.
A European scallop (Pecten opercularis), used as food. [Prov.Eng.]
The California salmon (Oncorhynchus choicha); -- called alsochouicha, king salmon, chinnook salmon, and Sacramento salmon. It isof great commercial importance. [Written also quinnet.]
The office, or the term of office, of a questor.
The inner or body garments taken together. See Cuerpo. Dryden.
Same as Pentavalent.
A kind of delicate forcemeat, commonly poached and used as adish by itself or for garnishing.

Having the leaves of a pentamerous calyx or corolla soimbricated that two are exterior, two are interior, and the other hasone edge exterior and one interior; as, quincuncial æstivation.Quincuncial phyllotaxy (Bot.), an arrangement of five leaves in aspiral, each leaf two fifths of a circle from the next.
Having trunnions the axes of which lie below the bore; -- saidof a cannon.
Kindly; merciful. [Obs.] Wyclif.
In so far as; in the capacity or character of; as.It is with Shelley's biographers qua biographers that we have todeal. London Spectator.
The four aces, kings, queens, knaves, or tens, in the game ofpiquet; -- so called because quatorze counts as fourteen points.
A candidate for honors or degrees who is near the time of hisexamination.
The state of being quaky; liability to quake.
Squat; flat. [Obs.] Shak.
A rawhide whip plaited with two thongs of buffalo hide T.Roosevelt.
Wharfage. [Also keyage.]
The quality or state of being queer.
The quarter of a circle, or of the circumference of a circle,an arc of 90º, or one subtending a right angle at the center.
Acute of smell.
Quarrelsome. [Obs.] [Written also quarrellous.] Shak.
To please. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a queasy manner.
A quarry. [Prov. Eng.] B. Jonson.
That part of the upper deck abaft the mainmast, including thepoop deck when there is one.
One who makes, or is given to making, quotations.The narrow intellectuals of quotationists. Milton.
A chronic abscess, or fistula of the coronet, in a horse'sfoot, resulting from inflammation of the tissues investing the coffinbone.

The bark of a rosaceous tree (Quillaja Saponaria), native ofChili. The bark is finely laminated, and very heavy with alkalinesubstances, and is used commonly by the Chilians instead of soap.Also called soap bark.
A galley having five benches or banks of oars; as, an Athenianquinquereme.
To search for; to examine. [R.] Sir T. Herbert.
Quietness. [Obs.] Spenser.
Any one of several kinds of apples, as summer queening, scarletqueening, and early queening. An apple called the queening wascultivated in England two hundred years ago.
Same as Quadrate.
To throb; to quiver. [Local & Vulgar]

A nitrogenous base, C9H7N obtained as a pungent colorlessliquid by the distillation of alkaloids, bones, coal tar, etc. It thenucleus of many organic bodies, especially of certain alkaloids andrelated substances; hence, by extension, any one of the series ofalkaloidal bases of which quinoline proper is the type. [Written alsochinoline.]
The state or condition of being questionable. Stallo.
A little quarrel. See 1st Quarrel, 2. [Obs.] "Quarrelets ofpearl [teeth]." Herrick.
Leather softened by boiling so as to take any required shape.Upon drying, it becomes exceedingly hard, and hence was formerly usedfor armor. [Obs.] "His jambeux were of quyrboilly." Chaucer.
In a quixotic way.
See the Note under Quit, a.
The most powerful, and except the king the most important,piece in a set of chessmen.
The fourth part; a quarter; hence, a region of the earth.[Obs.]Camber did possess the western quart. Spenser.
See Camass.
A trifle; a kickshaw. Donne.
A complaint to a court. See Audita Querela. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
A quarterly allowance.
In a quaking manner; fearfully. Sir P. Sidney.
In a quiescent manner.
Murder. [Obs.] Shak.
A genus of trees constituted by the oak. See Oak.
An unfledged bird; hence, something immature or unfinished.Ford.
Having four horns, or hornlike organs; as, a quadricornousbeetle.
One who discusses any subject at pleasure.
imp. of Quake. [Obs.] Spenser.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C15H26, of the valylene series,produced artificially as an oily liquid. [Written also quindekone.]
Consisting of forty; forty years old.
A coating of strands of rope for a water vessel.
Having five cells or loculi; five-celled; as, a quinquelocularpericarp.
Consisting of five letters.
Like or pertaining to a Quaker; Quakerlike.
The interval of a fifth.
= Questionary, above.

Relating to quantity.-- Quan"ti*ta*tive*ly, adv. Quantitative analysis (Chem.), analysiswhich determines the amount or quantity of each ingredient of asubstance, by weight or by volume; -- contrasted with qualitativeanalysis.
One of the Quadrumana.
The seeds of a kind of goosewort (Chenopodium Quinoa), used inChili and Peru for making porridge or cakes; also, food thus made.
A car or chariot drawn by four horses abreast.
Craft or skill in policy on the part of a queen.Elizabeth showed much queencraft in procuring the votes of thenobility. Fuller.
Quitch grass.
Massive quartz occurring as a rock; a metamorphosed sandstone;-- called also quartz rock.
Pertaining to, or designating, a crystalline acid obtained fromsome varieties of cinchona bark. [Written also chinovic, andkinovic.]
In a queer or odd manner.
To a fourfold quantity; so as to be, or cause to be, quadruple;as, to be quadruply recompensed.
The number resulting from the division of one number byanother, and showing how often a less number is contained in agreater; thus, the quotient of twelve divided by four is three.
Arranged in five vertical rows; pentastichous. Gray.

The nut of an Australian tree (Macadamia ternifolia). It isabout an inch in diameter, and contains a single round edible seed,or sometimes two hemispherical seeds. So called from Queensland inAustralia.
One of a sacerdotal college of fifteen men whose chief duty wasto take care of the Sibylline books.
Calm; still. [Obs.] Spenser.
The American night heron. See under Night.
Studious of profit. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Of the fifth degree or order.-- n. (Alg.)
A medusa, or jellyfish. [R.]The jellied quarl that flings At once a thousand streaming stings. J.R. Drake.
A glucoside extracted from the bark of the oak (Quercus) as abitter citron-yellow crystalline substance, used as a pigment andcalled quercitron.
The state, rank, or dignity of a queen.
The fifteenth century, when applied to Italian art orliterature; as, the sculpture of the quattrocento; quattrocentostyle. --Quat`tro*cen"tist (#), n.
A worker in a stone quarry.
The act of making fourfold; a taking four times the simple sumor amount.
Having ready wit Shak.
Valence. [Archaic]

Having a valence of four; capable of combining with, beingreplaced by, or compared with, four monad atoms; tetravalent; -- saidof certain atoms and radicals; thus, carbon and silicon arequadrivalent elements.

A contrivance employed by the ancient Peruvians, Mexicans,etc., as a substitute for writing and figures, consisting of a maincord, from which hung at certain distances smaller cords of variouscolors, each having a special meaning, as silver, gold, corn,soldiers. etc. Single, double, and triple knots were tied in thesmaller cords, representing definite numbers. It was chiefly used forarithmetical purposes, and to register important facts and events.[Written also quipo.] Tylor.The mysterious science of the quipus . . . supplied the Peruvianswith the means of communicating their ideas to one another, and oftransmitting them to future generations. Prescott.

A colorless liquid of a slightly pungent odor, C9H6N.CH3, firstobtained as a condensation product of aldehyde and aniline, andregarded as a derivative of quinoline; -- called also methylquinoline. [Written also chinaldine.]
The act of shaking, or the state of being shaken. Gayton.
Having a face left as it comes from the quarry and not smoothedwith the chisel or point; -- said of stones.
One who seeks; a seeker. [Obs.]
The off-spring of an octoroon and a white person.
Sharply cut about halfway to the middle or base into fivesegments; as, a quinquefid leaf or corolla.
In a quick manner; quickly; promptly; rapidly; with haste;speedily; without delay; as, run quick; get back quick.If we consider how very quick the actions of the mind are performed.Locke.
One who quaffs, or drinks largely.
Having four leaves to the sheet; of the form or size of aquarto.
See Quintain.
That branch of algebra which treats of quadratic equations.

An alkaloid isomeric with, and resembling, quinine, found incertain species of cinchona, from which it is extracted as a bitterwhite crystalline substance; conchinine. It is used somewhat as afebrifuge. [Written also chinidine.]
The act or habit of quizzing.
In the manner or order of a quincunx.

One legally empowered to make quest of certain matters, esp. ofabuses of weights and measures. Specifically:(a) A churchwarden's assistant; a sidesman. Blount. [Obs.](b) A collector of parish rents. Blount. [Obs.]
Dehiscent into four similar parts; four-valved; as, aquadrivalve pericarp.
Like Don Quixote; romantic to extravagance; absurdly chivalric;apt to be deluded. "Feats of quixotic gallantry." Prescott.
A rent reserved in grants of land, by the payment of which thetenant is quit from other service. Blackstone.
To conduct a quiz. See Quiz, n., 4. [U.S.]
Growing in sets of five; -- said especially of leaves composedof five leaflets set at the end of a common petiole.
See Querl.
Not restricted to a particular subject; discussed for curiosityor entertainment.-- Quod`li*bet"ic*al*ly, adv.
The aspect of planets when separated the fifth part of thezodiac, or 72º. Hutton.
Having quick sight or acute discernment; quick to see or todiscern. Locke. --Quick"-sight`ed*ness, n.
A thick, bushy plot; a thicket. [Obs.] Chapman.
The dominion, condition, or character of a queen. Mrs.Browning.
Same as Quipu.
A half farthing. [Obs.]
To suffocate; to choke. [Prov. Eng.]
Quadrinomial. Sir W. R. Hamilton.
Same as Quadrennial.
A yellow crystalline substance produced artificially. It isisomeric with alizarin.
See 2d Quarteron.
To shorten the radius of (a curve); to make (a curve) sharper;as, to quicken the sheer, that is, to make its curve more pronounced.
Composed of, or arranged in, sets of four; quaternary; as,quaternate leaves.
The bitter principle of quassia, extracted as a whitecrystalline substance; -- formerly called quassite. [Written alsoquassiin, and quassine.]
Butane, each molecule of which has four carbon atoms.
Quartzose.
Querulous. [R.]
One who quibbles; a caviler; also, a punster.
A game played by four persons with forty cards, being theremainder of an ordinary pack after the tens, nines, and eights arediscarded. Hoyle.
A punting pole with a broad flange near the end to prevent itfrom sinking into the mud; a setting pole.
A plane figure having four angles, and consequently four sides;any figure having four angles.
An uncrystallizable alkaloid obtained by the action of heatfrom quinine, with which it is isomeric.
Having four sides, and consequently four angles; quadrangular.
The fifteenth day after a feast day, including both in thereckoning. [Written also quinzain.]
A chorister. See Chorister. [R.] Thomson.
Having four teeth; as, a quadridentate leaf.
The European ringdove (Columba palumbus); the cushat. [Writtenalso quist, queeze, quice, queece.] See Ringdove.
Quixotism; visionary schemes.
That which qualifies, modifies, or restricts; a qualifying termor statement.How many qualificatives, correctives, and restrictives he insertethin this relation. Fuller.
A space or period of four years.
The quality of being queenly; the; characteristic of a queen;stateliness; eminence among women in attractions or power.

A yellow crystalline substance, occurring quite widelydistributed in the vegetable kingdom, as is apple-tree bark, horse-chestnut leaves, etc., but originally obtained by the decompositionof quercitrin. Called also meletin.
An interval of a fifth; also, a part sung with such intervals.[Obs.] "He sang . . . a loud quynyble." Chaucer.
A small South American opossum (Didelphys quica), native ofGuiana and Brazil. It feeds upon insects, small birds, and fruit.
imp. of Quake. Chaucer.
Somebody; one unknown. Spenser.
A truss framed with queen-posts; a queen-post truss.
Having four capsules.
Herring taken and cured or smoked near Quoddy Head, Maine, ornear the entrance of Passamaquoddy Ray.
Quiddative.
A quadrangle or court, as of a prison; hence, a prison. [Slang]"Flogged or whipped in quod." T. Hughes.
One who, or that which, quickens.
A mole, bank, or wharf, formed toward the sea, or at the sideof a harbor, river, or other navigable water, for convenience inloading and unloading vessels. [Written also key.]
The wolverine.

a. & n. from Quake, v. Quaking aspen (Bot.), an Americanspecies of poplar (Populus tremuloides), the leaves of which tremblein the lightest breeze. It much resembles the European aspen. SeeAspen.-- Quaking bog, a bog of forming peat so saturated with water thatit shakes when trodden upon.-- Quaking grass. (Bot.) (a) One of several grasses of the genusBriza, having slender-stalked and pendulous ovate spikelets, whichquake and rattle in the wind. Briza maxima is the large quakinggrass; B. media and B. minor are the smaller kinds. (b) Rattlesnakegrass (Glyceria Canadensis).
Having four feet; of or pertaining to a quadruped.
To cause to quake. [Obs.] Shak.
The acts, arts, or boastful pretensions of a quack; falsepretensions to any art; empiricism. Carlyle.
See Quaintise. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Arranged in four rows or ranks; as, quadrifarious leaves.Loudon.
See Coif. Shak.
A state of difficulty or perplexity; doubt; uncertainty.
Pertaining to, or designating, a tannic acid found in oak barkand extracted as a yellowish brown amorphous substance.
Sick at the stomach; affected with nausea or sickly languor;inclined to vomit. Shak.-- Qualm"ish*ly, adv.-- Qualm"ish*ness, n.
Of the fourth degree.

Anything that is quilted; esp., a quilted bed cover, or a skirtworn by women; any cover or garment made by putting wool, cotton,etc., between two cloths and stitching them together; also, any outerbed cover.The beds were covered with magnificent quilts. Arbuthnot.
Not sounded; silent; as, y is quiescent in "day" and "say."
A radical of which quinone is the hydride, analogous to phenyl.[Written also kinoyl.]
Overlaid with quicksilver, or with an amalgam of quicksilverand tinfoil.
The squinancy. Called also quinsywort.
Relating to quizzing: given to quizzing; of the nature of aquiz; farcical; sportive.-- Quiz"zic*al*ly, adv.
Return; requital; quittance. [Obs.]
The position of planets when distant from each other fivesigns, or 150º. Hutton.
any one of a series of nitrogenous bases, certain of which areused as antipyretics.
Relating to the five articles or points; as, thequinquarticular controversy between Arminians and Calvinists. [Obs.]Bp. Sanderson.
A California sciænoid food fish (Seriphys politus). The back isbluish, and the sides and belly bright silvery. Called also kingfish.
See Quaver. [Obs.]
The challenge of a French sentinel, or patrol; -- used like theEnglish challenge: "Who comes there" To be on the qui vive, to be onguard; to be watchful and alert, like a sentinel.
Having five nerves; -- said of a leaf with five nearly equalnerves or ribs rising from the end of the petiole.

The wood of several tropical American trees of the orderSimarubeæ, as Quassia amara, Picræna excelsa, and Simaruba amara. Itis intensely bitter, and is used in medicine and sometimes as asubstitute for hops in making beer.

A perennial grass (Agropyrum repens) having long runningrootstalks, by which it spreads rapidly and pertinaciously, and sobecomes a troublesome weed. Also called couch grass, quick grass,quick grass, twitch grass. See Illustration in Appendix.
One who quizzes; a quiz.
See Quaint. [Obs.]
That may be sqyared, or reduced to an equivalent square; --said of a surface when the area limited by a curve can be exactlyfound, and expressed in a finite number of algebraic terms.

As if; as though; as it were; in a manner sense or degree;having some resemblance to; qualified; -- used as an adjective, or aprefix with a noun or an adjective; as, a quasi contract, an impliedcontract, an obligation which has arisen from some act, as if from acontract; a quasi corporation, a body that has some, but not all, ofthe peculiar attributes of a corporation; a quasi argument, thatwhich resembles, or is used as, an argument; quasi historical,apparently historical, seeming to be historical.
Quadrinomial.

A form of silica, or silicon dioxide (SiO2), occurring inhexagonal crystals, which are commonly colorless and transparent, butsometimes also yellow, brown, purple, green, and of other colors;also in cryptocrystalline massive forms varying in color and degreeof transparency, being sometimes opaque.

That form of delusion which leads to extravagant and absurdundertakings or sacrifices in obedience to a morbidly romantic idealof duty or honor, as illustrated by the exploits of Don Quixote inknight-errantry.
A fourth part of the coin called an as. See 3d As, 2.

Relating to quality; having the character of quality.-- Qual"i*ta*tive*ly, adv. Qualitative analysis (Chem.), analysiswhich merely determines the constituents of a substance without anyregard to the quantity of each ingredient; -- contrasted withquantitative analysis.
An officer whose business it is to examine and prepare causesfor trial in the ecclesiastical courts.
Apt or disposed to quarrel; given to brawls and contention;easily irritated or provoked to contest; irascible; choleric.
The naming or publishing of the current price of stocks, bonds,or any commodity; also the price named.
An officer who had the management of the public treasure; areceiver of taxes, tribute, etc.; treasurer of state. [Written alsoquæstor.]
Part or proportion; quota. [R.] "A very small quotum." MaxMüller.
To name the current price of.
Fourfold; as, to make quadruple restitution; a quadruplealliance. Quadruple time (Mus.), that in which each measure isdivided into four equal parts.
Of the nature of a quagmire; yielding or trembling under thefoot, as soft, wet earth; spongy; boggy. "O'er the watery strath, orquaggy moss." Collins.
Capable of being quenched.
A quartet; -- applied chiefly to instrumental compositions.
Constituting, or containing, the essence of a thing;quidditative.
See Koran.
Quakerism. [Obs.] Hallywell.
Nimble; active. [Obs.] " A little quiver fellow." Shak.
An amorphous bitter glucoside derived from cinchona and otherbarks. Called also quinova bitter, and quinova. [Written alsochinovin, and kinovin.]
Belonging to Lent; used in Lent; Lenten.
A drinking vessel. See Quaich.
A portion suitable to be chewed; a cud; as, a quid of tobacco.
An ovolo.
Same as Quinquelobate.
Having four ways meeting in a point. B. Jonson.

, the seventeenth letter of the English alphabet, has but onesound (that of k), and is always followed by u, the two letterstogether being sounded like kw, except in some words in which the uis silent. See Guide to Pronunciation, § 249. Q is not found inAnglo-Saxon, cw being used instead of qu; as in cwic, quick; cwen,queen. The name (ku) is from the French ku, which is from the Latinname of the same letter; its form is from the Latin, which derivedit, through a Greek alphabet, from the Phoenician, the ultimateorigin being Egyptian. Etymologically, q or qu is most nearly relatedto a (ch, tch), p, q, and wh; as in cud, quid, L. equus, ecus, horse,Gr. equine, hippic; L. quod which, E. what; L. aquila, E. eaqle; E.kitchen, OE. kichene, AS. cycene, L. coquina.
Capable or worthy of being quoted; as, a quotable writer; aquotable sentence.-- Quot`a*bit"i*ty, n. Poe.

Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the acrylic acidseries, metameric with crotonic acid, and obtained as a colorlessliquid; -- so called from having four carbon atoms in the molecule.Called also isocrotonic acid.
A discharge; an issue. [Obs.]To cleanse the quitture from thy wound. Chapman.
The quotient of two vectors, or of two directed right lines inspace, considered as depending on four geometrical elements, and asexpressible by an algebraic symbol of quadrinomial form.
Of the nature of a quintessence; purest. "Quintessentialextract of mediocrity." G. Eliot.

An inflammation of the throat, or parts adjacent, especially ofthe fauces or tonsils, attended by considerable swelling, painful andimpeded deglutition, and accompanied by inflammatory fever. Itsometimes creates danger of suffocation; -- called also squinancy,and squinzey.
Quite. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A white crystalline substance, C6H7(OH)5, found in acorns, thefruit of the oak (Quercus). It has a sweet taste, and is regarded asa pentacid alcohol.
The quadratojugal bone. Quadratojugal bone (Anat.), a bone atthe base of the lower jaw in many animals.
A quip; a gibe.
One who, or that which, quilts.
One of five commissioners appointed for some special object.

A Chilian apocynaceous tree (Aspidosperma Quebracho); also, itsbark, which is used as a febrifuge, and for dyspnoea of the lung, orbronchial diseases; -- called also white quebracho, to distinguish itfrom the red quebracho, a Mexican anacardiaceous tree (LoxopterygiumLorentzii) whose bark is said to have similar properties. J. Smith(Dict. Econ. Plants).

The metal mercury; -- so called from its resemblance to liquidsilver. Quicksilver horizon, a mercurial artificial horizon. Seeunder Horizon.-- Quicksilver water, a solution of mercury nitrate used inartificial silvering; quick water.
See Queest.
To modify or qualify with respect to quantity; to fix orexpress the quantity of; to rate.
Consisting of four hundred.
A galley with four banks of oars or rowers.
Having five angles or corners.

Of or pertaining to a quadrant; also, included in the fourthpart of a circle; as, quadrantal space. Quadrantal triangle, aspherical triangle having one side equal to a quadrant or arc of 90º.-- Quadrantal versor, a versor that expresses rotation through oneright angle.
The first Sunday after Easter; Low Sunday.

Any plant or species of the genus Isoetes, cryptogamous plantswith a cluster of elongated four-tubed rushlike leaves, rising from acorm, and containing spores in their enlarged and excavated bases.There are about seventeen American species, usually growing in themud under still, shallow water. So called from the shape of the shapeof the leaves.
A block of type metal lower than the letters, -- used inspacing and in blank lines. [Abbrev. quad.]
A quarter; esp., a quarter of a pound, or a quarter of ahundred. Piers Plowman.
A curve made use of in the quadrature of other curves; as thequadratrix, of Dinostratus, or of Tschirnhausen.
Consisting chiefly of quartz; containing quartz.
One of two suspending posts in a roof truss, or other framedtruss of similar form. See King-post.
Rest; repose; quiet; tranquillity. Shelley.
Final discharge or acquittance, as from debt or obligation;that which silences claims; (Fig.) rest; death.When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin. Shak.
Fiftieth. Quinquagesima Sunday, the Sunday which is thefiftieth day before Easter, both days being included in thereckoning; -- called also Shrove Sunday.
Same as 1st Quarrel. [Obs.] Fairfax.
The European rowan tree; -- called also quickbeam, andquickenbeam. See Rowan tree.
Having four hands; of or pertaining to the Quadrumana.
The quality or state of being questionable, doubtful, orsuspicious.
An indulgence of forty days, corresponding to the forty days ofancient canonical penance.

The act, process, or result (in the process of parting) ofalloying a button of nearly pure gold with enough silver to reducethe fineness so as to allow acids to attack and remove all metalsexcept the gold; -- called also inquartation. Compare Parting.
A combining form meaning four, four times, fourfold; as,quadricapsular, having four capsules.
A quagmire. [R.] "Crooked or straight, through quags or thornydells." Cowper.

A corporation consisting of a person or body of personsinvested with some of the qualities of an artificial person, thoughnot expressly incorporated, esp. the official of certain municipaldivisions such as counties, schools districts, and the towns of someStates of the United States, certain church officials, as achurchwarden, etc.
To stifle or choke. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
See Cuish.
To twirl; to turn or wind round; to coil; as, to querl a cord,thread, or rope. [Local, U.S.]
One who inquires, or asks questions. Swift.
A groom; an equerry. [Obs.]
Same as Tetrabasic.
The state of being qualified.
Triflingly; evasively.
Having four ribs.
Dipping toward all points of the compass round a center, asbeds of lava round a crater.
The Indian ferret.
A quire; a book. [Obs.] " The king's quhair." James I. (ofScotland).
Having been formerly; former; sometime. "This is the quondamking." Shak.
Quadrable. [R.]
Coming from a point well abaft the beam, but not directlyastern; -- said of waves or any moving object.
Quackery. Carlyle.
One who quotes the words of another.
The property of being quadrilateral.
A plane figure with fifteen angles, and consequently fifteensides.

To saw (a log) into quarters; specif., to saw into quarters andthen into boards, as by cutting alternately from each face of aquarter, to secure lumber that will warp relatively little or showthe grain advantageously.
A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort; agibe.Quips, and cranks, and wanton wiles. Milton.He was full of joke and jest, But all his merry quips are o'er.Tennyson.
A living plant set to grow, esp. when set for a hedge;specifically, the hawthorn.
Incapable of being quenched; inextinguishable; as, quenchlessfire or fury. "Once kindled, quenchless evermore." Byron.
Provided with prey.Now I am bravely quarried. Beau. & Fl.
A hypothetical radical of quinine and related alkaloids.
To utter with quavers.We shall hear her quavering them . . . to some sprightly airs of theopera. Addison.
The four "liberal arts," arithmetic, music, geometry, andastronomy; -- so called by the schoolmen. See Trivium.
A division or distribution by four, or into four parts; also, ataking the fourth part of any quantity or number.
A South African wild ass (Equus, or Hippotigris, quagga). Theupper parts are reddish brown, becoming paler behind and behind andbeneath, with dark stripes on the face, neck, and fore part of thebody.
, One who, or that which, qualifies; that which modifies,reduces, tempers or restrains.

Modification by a reference to quantity; the introduction ofthe element of quantity.The quantification of the predicate belongs in part to Sir WilliamHamilton; viz., in its extension to negative propositions. DeQuincey.
See Choir. [Obs.] Spenser.A quire of such enticing birds. Shak.
One who quavers; a warbler.
A woman who is a member of the Society of Friends.
Of or pertaining to quantivalence. [Archaic]
p. p. of Quail. [Obs.] Spenser.
Like, becoming, or suitable to, a queen.
A small piece of money, in value about a farthing, or a halfcent. [Obs.]
A boastful pretender to medical skill; an empiric; an ignorantpractitioner.
Consisting of four letters.
Indeed; forsooth.To affront the blessed hillside drabs and thieves With mended morals,quotha, -- fine new lives ! Mrs. Browning.
A ruff for the neck. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
To distil or extract as a quintessence; to reduce to aquintessence. [R.] Stirling. "Truth quintessenced and raised to thehighest power." J. A. Symonds.
Occurring once in five years, or at the end of every fiveyears; also, lasting five years. A quinquennial event.

The act of squaring; the finding of a square having the samearea as some given curvilinear figure; as, the quadrature of acircle; the operation of finding an expression for the area of afigure bounded wholly or in part by a curved line, as by a curve, twoordinates, and the axis of abscissas.
One who is curious to know everything that passes; one whoknows, or pretends to know, all that is going on. "The idle storiesof quidnuncs." Motley.
Having four forks, or branches.
Any one of a series of complex nitrogenous bases obtained bythe union of certain aniline derivatives with glyoxal or with certainketones. [Written also chinoxaline.]
Of or pertaining to the quadriceps.
One of the Quirites.
A writ brought before a proper tribunal, to inquire by whatwarrant a person or a corporation acts, or exercises certain powers.Blackstone.
Divided, or deeply cleft, into four parts; as, a quadrifidperianth; a quadrifid leaf.
A subdivision into four parts.
To stir; to wince. [Obs.] Spenser.
The edible drupaceous fruit of an Australian tree (Fusanusacuminatus) of the Sandalwood family; -- called also quandang.

A crystalline substance, C6H4O2 (called also benzoketone),first obtained by the oxidation of quinic acid and regarded as adouble ketone; also, by extension, any one of the series of whichquinone proper is the type. [Written also chinone, kinone.]
To cause to fail in spirit or power; to quell; to crush; tosubdue. [Obs.] Spenser.
Having five angles; quinquangular.
Same as Butylene.
Such a number of the officers or members of any body as iscompetent by law or constitution to transact business; as, a quorumof the House of Representatives; a constitutional quorum was notpresent.
Furnished with qualities; endowed. [Obs.] "He was wellqualitied." Chapman.
The state, personality, or character of a queen; queenliness.Tennyson.

Furnished with quills; also, shaped like quills. "A sharp-quilled porcupine." Shak. Quilled suture (Surg.), a variety of stitchin which the threads after being passed deeply through the edges of awound are secured about two quills or bodies of similar shape, inorder to produce a suitable degree of pressure.
A cousin within the first four degrees of kindred.
Soft, wet, miry land, which shakes or yields under the feet. "Aspot surrounded by quagmires, which rendered it difficult of access."Palfrey.
A crying for help. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Formerly, a genus of plants including the cypress vine(Quamoclit vulgaris, now called Ipomoea Quamoclit). The genus is nowmerged in Ipomoea.
A supposed fourth integument of an ovule, counting from theoutside.
Engaged in a quarrel; apt or disposed to quarrel; as,quarreling factions; a quarreling mood.-- Quar"rel*ing*ly, adv.
A mill for grinding grain, the upper stone of which was turnedby hand; -- used before the invention of windmills and watermills.Shak.They made him at the querne grind. Chaucer.
A confection of quinces, in consistency between a sirup andmarmalade.
One who, or that which, quenches. Hammond.
A form of crystal common with quartz, consisting of two six-sided pyramids, base to base.
Having, or formed with, a quirk or quirks.
In a quaint manner. Shak.
A tetroxide. [R.]
See Quagmire. [Obs.]
In four parts.
One who, or that which, quiets.

Properly, a kind of superior olive grown in the region ofSeville, Spain. It is large size and oblong shape with a small butlong pit; it is cured when green, keeps well, and has a delicateflavor. Loosely, any olive of similar character.
A long and stout staff formerly used as a weapon of defense andoffense; -- so called because in holding it one hand was placed inthe middle, and the other between the middle and the end.
One who boasts of his skill in medicines and salves, or of theefficacy of his prescriptions; a charlatan; a quack; a mountebank.[Obs.] Burton.
The hypothetical radical of certain quinone derivatives relatedto rhodizonic acid.
Inquiring; asking questions; testing. "Questionary epistles."Pope.
Unquestioning; incurious. [R.]

A division of the Primates comprising the apes and monkeys; --so called because the hind foot is usually prehensile, and the greattoe opposable somewhat like a thumb. Formerly the Quadrumana wereconsidered an order distinct from the Bimana, which last included manalone.

A release or relinquishment of a claim; a deed of release; aninstrument by which some right, title, interest, or claim, which oneperson has, or is supposed to have, in or to an estate held byhimself or another, is released or relinquished, the grantorgenerally covenanting only against persons who claim under himself.
The science which treats of the cultivation of the cinchona,and of its use in medicine.
A polynomial of four terms connected by the signs plus orminus.
A complex nitrogenous base related to cinnoline. [Written alsochinazol.]
Quarzose.
Public games celebrated every five years.
The peculiar character, manners, tenets, etc., of the Quakers.
Of or pertaining to the Quietists, or to Quietism.
The great extensor muscle of the knee, divided above into fourparts which unite in a single tendon at the knee.
To satiate; to satisfy. [Prov. Eng.]
A medley improvised by several performers.
Divided into four parts.
The forty days of fast preceding Easter; Lent. QuadragesimaSunday, the first Sunday in Lent, about forty days before Easter.
A marsupial of Australia (Dasyurus macrurus), about the size ofa cat.

The system of the Quietists, who maintained that religionconsists in the withdrawal of the mind from worldly interests andanxieties and its constant employment in the passive contemplation ofGod and his attributes.
One who lays informations, and encourages petty lawsuits.[Obs.] Bacon.
Divided into five parts almost to the base.
Consisting of five; arranged by fives. Boyle. Quinary system(Zoöl.), a fanciful classification based on the hypothesis that eachgroup contains five types.
An officer whose duty is to provide quarters, provisions,storage, clothing, fuel, stationery, and transportation for aregiment or other body of troops, and superintend the supplies.

Any small square or quadrangular member; as:(a) A square of glass, esp. when set diagonally.(b) A small opening in window tracery, of which the cusps, etc., makethe form nearly square.(c) A square or lozenge-shaped paving tile.
A man who is engaged in quarrying stones; a quarrier.
Possessing four nodes; as, quadrinodal curves.
The middle of the three groups into which the rocks of theCanadian period have been divided in the American Lower Siluriansystem. See the Chart of Geology.
Of or pertaining to the second degree.
Estimable according to quantity; quantitative. Sir K. Digby.
The quagga.
One who asks questions; an inquirer. "Little time for idlequestioners." Tennyson.
The upland plover. [Canadian]

a quince tree or shrub. Japan quince (Bot.), an Eastern Asiaticshrub (Cydonia, formerly Pyrus, Japonica) and its very fragrant butinedible fruit. The shrub has very showy flowers, usually red, butsometimes pink or white, and is much grown for ornament.-- Quince curculio (Zoöl.), a small gray and yellow curculio(Conotrachelus cratægi) whose larva lives in quinces.-- Quince tree (Bot.), the small tree (Cydonia vulgaris) whichproduces the quince.

A homogeneous algebraic function of two or more variables, ingeneral containing only positive integral powers of the variables,and called quadric, cubic, quartic, etc., according as it is of thesecond, third, fourth, fifth, or a higher degree. These are furthercalled binary, ternary, quaternary, etc., according as they containtwo, three, four, or more variables; thus, the quantic is a binarycubic.
Capable of being qualified; abatable; modifiable. Barrow.
A brownish resinous substance obtained as a by-product in thetreatment of cinchona bark. It consists of a mixture of severalalkaloids. [Written also chinoidine.]
A complaint or complaining. [Obs.] E. Hall.
A heifer. [Scot.]
The common guillemot. [Prov. Eng.]

A definite portion of a manifoldness, limited by a mark or by aboundary. W. K. Clifford. Quantum meruit ( Etym: [L., as much as hemerited] (Law), a count in an action grounded on a promise that thedefendant would pay to the plaintiff for his service as much as heshould deserve.-- Quantum sufficit (, or Quantum suff. Etym: [L., as much suffices](Med.), a sufficient quantity.-- Quantum valebat ( Etym: [L., as much at it was worth] (Law), acount in an action to recover of the defendant, for goods sold, asmuch as they were worth. Blackstone.
A fifteenth. [Obs.] Prynne.
Complaining; querulous; apt to complain.-- Quer`i*mo"ni*ous*ly, adv.-- Quer`i*mo"ni*ous*ness, n.
The relation of an object to number. Krauth-Fleming.

Pertaining to, derived from, or connected with, quinine andrelated compounds; specifically, designating a nonnitrogenous acidobtained from cinchona bark, coffee, beans, etc., as a whitecrystalline substance. [Written also chinic, kinic.]

An alkaloid extracted from the bark of several species ofcinchona (esp. Cinchona Calisaya) as a bitter white crystallinesubstance, C20H24N2O2. Hence, by extension (Med.), any of the saltsof this alkaloid, as the acetate, chloride, sulphate, etc., employedas a febrifuge or antiperiodic. Called also quinia, quinina, etc.[Written also chinine.]
See Coiffure.
Quarterage. [Obs.]
Having four cells, or cavities; as, a quadrilocular heart.
The long-tailed, or resplendent, trogon (Pharomachus mocinno,formerly Trogon resplendens), native of Southern Mexico and CentralAmerica. Called alsoquetzal, and golden trogon.

The first motion of the fetus in the womb felt by the mother,occurring usually about the middle of the term of pregnancy. It hasbeen popularly supposed to be due to the fetus becoming possessed ofindependent life.

Sand easily moved or readily yielding to pressure; especially,a deep mass of loose or moving sand mixed with water, sometimes foundat the mouth of a river or along some coasts, and very dangerous,from the difficulty of extricating a person who begins sinking intoit.Life hath quicksands, -- Life hath snares! Longfellow.
A kind of beer. Same as Quass.
The embryonic sac of an ovule, sometimes regarded as aninnermost fifth integument. Cf. Quartine, and Tercine.
The old squaw. [Local, U. S.]
Same as Questor.
To become extinguished; to go out; to become calm or cool. [R.]Dost thou think in time She will not quench! Shak.
An object to be tilted at; -- called also quintel. [Writtenalso quintin.]
A poem of fourteen lines; a sonnet. R. H. Stoddard.
A method of training trees or shrubs in the shape of a cone ordistaff by tying down the branches and pruning.
To spend time in trifling employments, or to attend to usefulsubjects in an indifferent or superficial manner; to dawdle.
Same as Squash.
Having four angles, and consequently four sides; tetragonal.-- Quad*ran"gu*lar*ly, adv.
Shaky, or tremulous; quaking.
Like a quack; boasting; characterized by quackery. Burke.
So as to be measurable by quantity; quantitatively.
Sulphur. [Obs.]
Subtilty; nicety; quibble. "Nice, sharp quillets of the law."Shak.
Same as Quadrijugous.
See Quicken tree.
The mercury and foil on the back of a looking-glass.
Of or pertaining to the fourth; occurring every fourth day,reckoning inclusively; as, a quartan ague, or fever.
Capable of being quitted.
Readiness of wit. "Celtic quick-wittedness." M. Arnold.
Any one of numerous species of small passerine birds native oftropical America. See Banana quit, under Banana, and Guitguit.
Speedily; with haste or celerity; soon; without delay; quick.
A piece of ground taken out of any regular ground plot orfloor, so as to make a court, yard, etc.; -- sometimes written quink.Gwilt.
Counterfeit money. [Slang] To shove the queer, to putcounterfeit money in circulation. [Slang]
Having four valves; quadrivalve.
Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now,commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corneris marked.
With quivering motion.
A platform of a staircase where the stair turns at a rightangle only. See Halfpace.
See Coil. [Obs.]
To quaver. [Obs.] See Quob.
Like a Quaker.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barleymeal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians. [writtenalso quas.]
See Quintain.
See Quit. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A group of five notes to be played or sung in the time of fourof the same species.
Occurring or returning daily; as, a quotidian fever.
In the way of qualification; with modification orqualification.
A subtilty; an equivocation. [Obs.] Shak.By some strange quiddit or some wrested clause. Drayton.
Containing, or resembling, quartz; partaking of the nature orqualities of quartz.
The quality or state of being quadrivalent; tetravalence.
In a questionable manner.
An American fresh-water fish (Ictiobus, or Carpiodes,cyprinus); -- called also carp sucker, sailfish, spearfish, andskimback.
To make fourfold; to double twice; to quadruple.
Roman citizens.
One of a sect of mystics originated in the seventeenth centuryby Molinos, a Spanish priest living in Rome. See Quietism.
Peruvian bark.
To be silent, as a letter; to have no sound. M. Stuart.
A game played with quoits. Shak.
One who undertakes a quest; a seeker. [Obs.] Shak.
Resembling Quakers; Quakerlike; Quakerish. Macaulay.
The state of being queasy; nausea; qualmishness; squeamishness.Shak.

According to the French notation, which is followed also uponthe Continent and in the United States, a unit with fifteen ciphersannexed; according to the English notation, the number produced byinvolving a million to the fourth power, or the number represented bya unit with twenty-four ciphers annexed. See the Note underNumeration.
A lively, spirited march; also, a lively style of dancing.
Calcium oxide; unslacked lime; -- so called because when wet itdevelops great heat. See 4th Lime, 2.
Having four leaves; quadrifoliate.
A card, die. or domino, having four spots, or pips
To drink with relish; to drink copiously of; to swallow inlarge draughts. "Quaffed off the muscadel." Shak.They eat, they drink, and in communion sweet Quaff immortality andjoy. Milton.
Rather queer; somewhat singular.
Later than, or subsequent to, the Tertiary; Post-tertiary; as,the Quaternary age, or Age of man.
Space of five years.
The coaita.
To become still, silent, or calm; -- often with down; as, besoon quieted down.
Inquire; question; see; -- used to signify doubt or to suggestinvestigation.
A word of five syllables.

Said; spoke; uttered; -- used only in the first and thirdpersons in the past tenses, and always followed by its nominative,the word or words said being the object; as, quoth I. quoth he. "Letme not live, quoth he." Shak.
Same as 2d Carte.
Once in four years.
The quality or state of being quiet; freedom from noise,agitation, disturbance, or excitement; stillness; tranquillity;calmness.I would have peace and quietness. Shak.
Same as Quitch grass.
A combining form meaning five, five times, fivefold; as,quinquefid, five-cleft; quinquedentate, five-toothed.
Pinnate, with four pairs of leaflets; as, a quadrijugous leaf.
Any quadricornous animal.
A wagtail.
An aëroplane with four superposed main supporting surfaces.

Designating, or pertaining to, a linguistic stock of SouthAmerican Indians, including the majority of the civilized tribes ofthe ancient Peruvian Empire with some wild tribes never subjugated bythe Incas. Most of these Indians are short, but heavy and strong.They are brachycephalic and of remarkably low cranial capacity.Nevertheless, they represent one of the highest of native Americancivilizations, characterized by agricultural, military, andadministrative skill rather than by science or literature, althoughthey were adept potters, weavers, and goldsmiths, and preserved bythe aid of the mnemonic quipu a body of legendary lore in partwritten down since the introduction of writing.
To repay; to requite. [Obs.] Shak.
Having four hoofs; as, a quadrisulcate foot; a quadrisulcateanimal.
To fasten, as hair, in a queue.
A fifteenth part. [Obs.]
A word consisting of four syllables. De Quincey.
